title: 106_hr4465
content: The "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000" aims to equalize trade in textile and apparel goods between the United States and WTO member countries. The "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000" sets the policy for the United States to negotiate reciprocal market access in textile and apparel goods within the WTO. The President must determine if each WTO member country provides similar market access for US textile and apparel goods. If access is less favorable, the President will impose measures. The "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000" requires the President to impose quotas, tariffs, or other measures on textile and apparel products of countries that do not provide similar market access for US goods. The President must negotiate agreements to remove trade barriers, and adjust measures if agreements are reached. The President must report actions to Congress by June 30 each year. The President is required to report to Congress annually on actions taken to impose measures on textile and apparel products of countries that do not provide similar market access for US goods. The report must include determinations made, measures implemented, negotiations undertaken, agreements reached, and measures adjusted. Definitions of "WTO" and "WTO member country" are provided in the Uruguay Round Agreements Act. SEC. 3. Civil actions for damages arising from fraudulent acts of importers allow producers, distributors, or retailers of textile or apparel goods to bring a civil action in Federal court against violators for damages incurred. The burden of proof is on the plaintiff to establish the violation by a preponderance of evidence. The remedy provided is exclusive and not available if damages have been recovered under another law. SEC. 4. Extension of benefit period for trade readjustment allowances for adversely affected workers enrolled in training programs. SEC. 4. Extension of benefit period for trade readjustment allowances for adversely affected workers enrolled in training programs. The benefit period is extended from 26 to 52 weeks for workers covered by a certification of eligibility issued under the Trade Act of 1974. SEC. 5. Credit for health insurance premiums paid by individuals receiving trade adjustment assistance. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section allowing individuals receiving trade adjustment assistance to claim a credit for health insurance costs. Individuals receiving trade adjustment assistance can claim a credit for 50% of the amount paid for qualified health insurance for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Qualified health insurance excludes coverage from employer or group health plans. Trade adjustment assistance refers to assistance provided under specific programs. The term 'trade adjustment assistance' refers to specific programs providing assistance. Special rules apply, including coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. Trade adjustment assistance is provided to textile and apparel workers facing job loss due to decreased sales or plant closures. The Secretary of Labor certifies eligibility for benefits within 30 days of a petition being filed. Effective starting in taxable years after December 31, 2000.
